item.title: Quest For Free Chicken Nuggets Inspires Twitter's Most Retweeted Tweet
item.description: May 9, 2017 - Carter Wilkerson was on a mission to get free chicken nuggets from Wendy's. In the process, he dethroned Ellen DeGeneres' Oscar selfie for the most retweets ever. Oh, and he also got the free nuggets.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 9, 2017 - Carter Wilkerson was on a mission to get free chicken nuggets from Wendy's. In the process, he dethroned Ellen DeGeneres' Oscar selfie for the most retweets ever. Oh, and he also got the free nuggets. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/09/527597422/quest-for-free-chicken-nuggets-inspires-twitters-most-retweeted-tweet

item.title: Austrian Court Rules Facebook Must Delete Hate Speech
item.description: May 8, 2017 - The decision could have global consequences: The court ruled that the harsh words against an Austrian politician must be deleted from Facebook worldwide.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 8, 2017 - The decision could have global consequences: The court ruled that the harsh words against an Austrian politician must be deleted from Facebook worldwide. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/08/527398995/austrian-court-rules-facebook-must-delete-hate-speech

item.title: After Decades Covering It, Tech Still Amazes Walt Mossberg
item.description: May 8, 2017 - He began covering personal technology in the 1990s, when he says tech columns were written "by geeks for geeks." As he retires, Mossberg reflects on how tech has evolved, often in unexpected ways.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 8, 2017 - He began covering personal technology in the 1990s, when he says tech columns were written "by geeks for geeks." As he retires, Mossberg reflects on how tech has evolved, often in unexpected ways. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/08/527407726/after-decades-covering-it-tech-still-amazes-walt-mossberg

item.title: Restaurants With Low Yelp Ratings Suffer Under Higher Minimum Wages
item.description: May 8, 2017 - Minimum wage increases in the San Francisco Bay Area have had an impact on the local restaurant industry, according to a study released by Harvard Business School. Restaurants with low or middling Yelp reviews have become more likely to go out of business. Places with high reviews have been unaffected. The study doesn't attempt to determine whether the wage increases have been good for employees or the local economy overall.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

The study doesn't attempt to determine whether the wage increases have been good for employees or the local economy overall. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/08/527452861/restaurants-with-low-yelp-ratings-suffer-under-higher-minimum-wages

item.title: When You're Not Quite Sure If Your Teacher Is Human
item.description: May 8, 2017 - When this computer science professor became overwhelmed with the number of questions students were asking, he recruited artificial intelligence to help serve up some answers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Google Moves In And Wants To Pump 1.5 Million Gallons Of Water Per Day
item.description: May 8, 2017 - The company says it needs that much water to cool its servers at a South Carolina data center. Now, community leaders are having to balance economic benefits with environmental impact.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: On The Eve Of French Election, Hackers Release Data From Macron Campaign
item.description: May 6, 2017 - French voters head to the polls on Sunday in the presidential election runoff. They're choosing between two candidates with starkly different views about the future of France.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 6, 2017 - French voters head to the polls on Sunday in the presidential election runoff. item.title: New Software Can Mimic Anyone's Voice
item.description:
May 5, 2017 - A company in Canada has come up with away to recreate anyone's voice and get it to say almost anything. It opens up dangerous possibilities, however.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/05/05/527013820/new-software-can-mimic-anyones-voice
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: FCC Chief Makes Case For Tackling Net Neutrality Violations 'After The Fact'
item.description: May 5, 2017 - FCC Chairman Ajit Pai is repealing Obama-era regulations for Internet providers. He tells NPR he prefers taking targeted action against actual harms, not preemptively regulating hypothetical ones.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 5, 2017 - FCC Chairman Ajit Pai is repealing Obama-era regulations for Internet providers. He tells NPR he prefers taking targeted action against actual harms, not preemptively regulating hypothetical ones. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/05/526916610/fcc-chief-net-neutrality-rules-treating-internet-as-utility-stifle-growth

item.title: Google Doc Users Hit By Massive Email Phishing Scam
item.description:
May 4, 2017 - A new phishing scam comes in the form of a Google doc link from what looks like a known source. An IT professional explains.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/05/04/526931972/google-doc-users-hit-by-massive-email-phishing-scam
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: EU Drops Its Antitrust Probe Over Amazon E-Book Contracts
item.description: May 4, 2017 - The European Union's executive arm closed the investigation after accepting Amazon's promise to strip its publisher contracts of clauses that the commission feared were "harmful to consumers."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: San Bernardino Victims' Families Accuse Tech Giants Of Enabling ISIS
item.description: May 4, 2017 - Facebook, Google and Twitter have been accused in a new lawsuit of aiding terrorism. The suit was filed by family members of three of the victims in the 2015 San Bernardino terrorist attack.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Morning News Brief: GOP Health Care Plan, Trump Eases Religious Group Restrictions
item.description: May 4, 2017 - After weeks of wrangling, the GOP will send a health care bill to a vote Thursday. Also, President Trump is expected to sign an executive order relaxing political restrictions on religious groups.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 4, 2017 - After weeks of wrangling, the GOP will send a health care bill to a vote Thursday. item.title: The Daredevils Without Landlines â€” And Why Health Experts Are Tracking Them
item.description: May 4, 2017 - It's official: A majority of U.S. homes only have mobile phones. But who knew wireless-only households were into risky behavior? A Centers for Disease Control and Prevention researcher explains.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Did You Get A Weird Invitation To Edit A Google Doc? It's Best Not To Click
item.description: May 3, 2017 - The reason: It's probably not legit. A vast phishing scam has been emailing malicious files masquerading as Google Docs. Does a recent edit invitation smell fishy to you? Just delete it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
